Award.AwardTitle: Novel Polypyridine Ligands: Synthesis, Characterization, and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project suppoerted by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism Program of the NSF Chemistry Division, Shih-Yuan Liu of the University of Oregon will develop polypyridine ligands in which a pyridine unit in 2-2'-bipyridine (bipy) is replaced by an isosteric 1,2-dihydro-1,2-azaborine heterocycle. This replacement results in low-symmetry polypyridyls ligands (BNbipy) that generate upon coordination with transition metals complexes that are isostructural to the corresponding metal bipyridine complexes. This isosteric replacement approach expands the diversity of accessible bipy ligands for coordination chemistry. The project encompasses synthesis of new boron-nitrogen heterocycles, coordination chemistry of BNbipy ligands, and physical methods for characterization of the new ligands and their transition metal complexes. Basic science in boron chemistry, coordination chemistry, and photophysical characterization of these new polypyridyl ligands and their corresponding metal complexes will be unraveled during these investigations.

2-2'-Bipyridine (bipy) is among the most important and widely used ligands in coordination chemistry. The proposed research seeks to utilize the BN/CC isosterism approach to expand the chemical space of bipy ligands. Successful accomplishment of this project will positively impact the fields of coordination chemistry, dye-sensitized solar cells, organic light-emitting diode materials development, and biomedical research that utilize bipy derivatives. The project will also provide comprehensive and diverse training to the graduate students and undergraduate students involved, including internship opportunities at national laboratories and private industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
BN/CC isosterism, i.e., the replacement of two carbon atoms with a boron and a nitrogen atom, has emerged as a viable strategy to expand the chemical space of organic compounds. BN/CC isosterism of the ubiquitous benzene motif leads to the so-called azaborine heterocycle. Despite the recent advances in BN heterocycle chemistry, the exploration of BN/CC isosteres of classic coordination ligands has remained underexplored. We have set out as a goal to develop the synthetic tools that can access new coordination ligands. With the support of the NSF, 1) we have successfully developed a scalable synthesis of a versatile 1,2-azaborine precursor, avoiding the use of a protecting group at the nitrogen position; 2) we have successfully developed a late-stage functionalization methodologies that can install a variety of substituents at the C3 and C6 positions of a 1,2-azaborine from an assembled readily accessible 1,2-azaborine intermediate. The new synthetic tool enabled the synthesis of the BN isostere of polyparaphenylene that exhibits a significantly longer effective conjugation length; 3) using the developed methodologies, we succeeded in synthesizing 2-pyridyl functionalized azaborines as new ligand scaffold, and prepared a corresponding boron complex; 4) we successfully developed the synthesis of a monobenzofused 1,4-azaborine ligand scaffold and determined that they engage in a unique κ2-η2-BC bonding with transition metals; 5) our understanding of the aromaticity of 1,2-azaborines has further been improved by the discovery of their Diels-Alder reactivity.

 

As a result of this project, we have published 8 papers (among them 3 in the J. Am. Chem. Soc. and 4 in Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.) and given 24 presentations (including 13 student presentations).

 

The NSF support has significantly contributed to the professional development of undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs, as well as encouraged high-school students to pursue a science career. During the award period, four Boston College undergraduate students from the PI’s lab have graduated and moved to a career in science, two graduate students have received their Ph.D. degrees and have become chemistry educators themselves at primarily undergraduate teaching institutions. Two postdocs have now moved on to become principle investigators and are now training chemistry students.

 

Our science outreach efforts include visits of graduate students to high schools to speak about the benefits of pursuing a degree in chemistry and perform hands-on chemistry demonstration. As a second avenue of our science outreach effort, we have introduced student-prepared teaching material on 1) arrow-pushing mechanisms of organic and organometallic transformations, 2) commonly used reagents and tactics in complex molecule synthesis, and 3) commonly encountered named reactions in total synthesis that are now available as a publically available online resource (http://capricorn.bc.edu/lsy/public_html/public-presentations.html).
